pages.text: This section is all about the Greenhouse and its various upgrades.$(p)The Greenhouse is a single-block machine which allows you to grow a variety of plants within a sustained mini-ecosystem automatically.
To begin, you will need to create the Greenhouse.

As seen on the left is an image of what you will see when you open the Greenhouse. There are a lot of slots, so here is a list of what is needed:$(li)A: $(#6b1f1f)Fertilizer.$() You can use $(l:items/fertilizer)Fertilizer$() or Bone Meal.$(li)B: $(2)Crops.$() This can be a wide range of things, documented later.$(li)C: $(#6b4242)Soil.$() This is dependent on the crop you use.$(li)D: $(9)Water.

In regards to the $(#6b1f1f)Fertilizer$() used, better quality will provide better results, as different grades of Fertilizer will multiply the output. In fact, using $(3)Chaotic Fertilizer$() will increase the yield by $(6)4x.$()$(p)In addition, most Fertilizers last for 20 or more operations before needing another unit, while Bone Meal only lasts 5.$(p)$(7)$(o)Food for thought...

Now, what to grow? There are MANY possibilities, including (but not limited to):$(li)Trees$(li)Flowers$(li)Coral$(li)Crops$(li)Chorus Fruit$(li)Nether Wart$(li)Crimson and Warped Fungi$(li)Melons and Pumpkins$(li)Seaweed and Sea Pickles$(li)Bamboo$(li)Glow Berries$(li)Chaos Plane vegetation

So, you just take what you want to grow and slam it into the Greenhouse? Not exactly.$(p)The first factor to consider is $(6)light requirements.$() Some crops require sunlight to grow, and some require complete darkness. In general, if it is grown above-ground in the Overworld, it needs sunlight. Most other crops that don't fit that criteria need darkness.$(br)$(4)Artificial light won't grow sunlight crops, and will stop darkness crops!

Now that you've gotten light requirements out of the way, next up for consideration is $(#6b4242)Soil.$() Soil is not consumed during operation, so you can just place one into the machine and it will self-sustain. Generally speaking, you need whatever your crop grows on as a soil, here is an example:$(li)Dirt-like blocks for crops, trees, and flowers$(li)Sand for Cacti, Sugar Cane, and Seaweed$(li)Soul Sand for Nether Crops

Finally, some crops will work as-is, like Wheat, Melons, or Sugar Cane, but some require one or more $(d)specialization upgrades$() in order to grow. Keep reading to learn about them.$(p)Now, as long as everything is supplied, the Greenhouse has power, and a crop is in, the Greenhouse will produce!

pages.title: Arborist
pages.text: The $(2)Arborist's Specialization$() upgrade supports the growth of Saplings in the Greenhouse. It's required for both Overworld tree types, as well as Crimson and Warped fungi.

pages.title: Florist
pages.text: The $(5)Florist's Specialization$() upgrade allows the growth of Flowers. It's required for all Overworld flowers, as well as some found in the Chaos Plane.

pages.title: Interdimensional
pages.text: The $(9)Interdimensional Specialization$() upgrade enables crops from other dimensions. It's needed for all Nether crops (Nether Wart and Crimson and Warped fungi), Chorus Fruit, and Chaos Plane crops (Prism Roses and Chaosbark Trees, to name a few).

pages.title: Blackout Glass
pages.text: The Blackout Glass upgrade blocks out all external light, allowing crops which $(5)require darkness$() to grow uninhibited regardless of light level. It will also speed up operation slightly.

pages.title: Internal Lamp
pages.text: The $(6)Internal Lamp$() upgrade simulates natural sunlight and allows $(6)daylight-only$() crops to grow in darkness. It will also speed up operation slightly.

If you are using $(9)Just Enough Items,$() there is a lot of info available beyond typical input and output, indicated in the image:$(li)A: The $(6)light requirement$() of the crop; a $(6)yellow$() arrow for daylight, and a $(5)purple$() arrow for darkness.$(li)B: The $(#6b4242)Soils$() accepted.$(li)C: 1-2 $(c)Upgrades$() required to grow the crop. This does not include optional ones, like Blackout Glass or Internal Lamp.
